Trajectory planning for Automatic Machines and Robots (2008)

3.4 Trajectory with Double S Velocity Profile

A trapezoidal (or triangular) velocity motion profile presents a discontinuous acceleration. For this reason, this trajectory may generate efforts and stresses on the mechanical system that may result detrimental or generate undesired vibrational effects (see Chapter 7 for a more detailed discussion on these aspects). Therefore, a smoother motion profile must be defined, for example by adopting a continuous, linear piece-wise, acceleration profile as shown in Fig. 3.13. In this manner, the resulting velocity is composed by linear segments connected by parabolic blends. The shape of the velocity profile is the reason of the name double SSS for this trajectory, known also as bell trajectory or seven segments trajectory, because it is composed by seven different tracts with constant jerk. Since the jerk is characterized by a step profile, the stress and the vibrational effects generated on the transmission chain and on the load by this motion profile are reduced with respect to trapezoidal velocity trajectories, characterized by an impulsive jerk profile.

Let us assume that

jmin⁡=−jmax⁡,amin⁡=−amax⁡,vmin⁡=−vmax⁡\mathrm{j}_{\min }=-\mathrm{j}_{\max }, \quad \mathrm{a}_{\min }=-\mathrm{a}_{\max }, \quad \mathrm{v}_{\min }=-\mathrm{v}_{\max }jmin​=−jmax​,amin​=−amax​,vmin​=−vmax​

where jmin⁡\mathrm{j}_{\min }jmin​ and jmax⁡\mathrm{j}_{\max }jmax​ are the minimum and maximum value of the jerk, respectively. With these conditions, it is desired to plan a trajectory that, when possible, reaches the maximum (minimum) values for jerk, acceleration and velocity so that the total duration TTT is minimized (minimum time trajectory). Only the case q1>q0q_{1}>q_{0}q1​>q0​ is now considered. The case q1<q0q_{1}<q_{0}q1​<q0​ is addressed in the following Sec. 3.4.2. Moreover, for the sake of simplicity, the value t0=0t_{0}=0t0​=0 is assumed. The boundary conditions are:

  • Generic initial and final values of velocity v0,v1\mathrm{v}_{0}, \mathrm{v}_{1}v0​,v1​.
  • Initial and final accelerations a0,a1\mathrm{a}_{0}, \mathrm{a}_{1}a0​,a1​ set to zero.

Three phases can be distinguished:

  1. Acceleration phase, t∈[0,Ta]t \in\left[0, T_{a}\right]t∈[0,Ta​], where the acceleration has a linear profile from the initial value (zero) to the maximum and then back to zero.
  2. Maximum velocity phase, t∈[Ta,Ta+Tv]t \in\left[T_{a}, T_{a}+T_{v}\right]t∈[Ta​,Ta​+Tv​], with a constant velocity.
  3. Deceleration phase, t∈[Ta+Tv,T]t \in\left[T_{a}+T_{v}, T\right]t∈[Ta​+Tv​,T], being T=Ta+Tv+TdT=T_{a}+T_{v}+T_{d}T=Ta​+Tv​+Td​, with profiles opposite with respect to the acceleration phase.

Given the constraints on the maximum values of jerk, acceleration and velocity, and given the desired displacement h=q1−q0h=q_{1}-q_{0}h=q1​−q0​, the trajectory is computed by using (3.30a)-(3.30g). However, it is first necessary to verify whether a trajectory can be actually performed or not. As a matter of fact, there are several cases in which a trajectory cannot be computed with the given constraints. For example, if the desired displacement hhh is small with respect to the difference between the initial and final velocities v0\mathrm{v}_{0}v0​ and v1\mathrm{v}_{1}v1​, it might be not possible

Fig. 3.13. Typical profiles for position, velocity, acceleration and jerk for the double S trajectory.

to change the velocity (with the given limits on jerk and acceleration), while accomplishing the displacement hhh.

The limit case is represented by a single acceleration (if v0<v1\mathrm{v}_{0}<\mathrm{v}_{1}v0​<v1​ ) or deceleration (if v0>v1\mathrm{v}_{0}>\mathrm{v}_{1}v0​>v1​ ) phase. Therefore, it is first necessary to check if it is possible to perform the trajectory with a double jerk impulse (one positive and one negative) only. For this purpose, let us define

Tj⋆=min⁡{∣v1−v0∣jmax⁡,amax⁡jmax⁡}\begin{equation*} T_{j}^{\star}=\min \left\{\sqrt{\frac{\left|\mathrm{v}_{1}-\mathrm{v}_{0}\right|}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }}}, \quad \frac{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }}\right\} \tag{3.17} \end{equation*}Tj⋆​=min{jmax​∣v1​−v0​∣​​,jmax​amax​​}​(3.17)​

If Tj⋆=amax⁡/jmax⁡T_{j}^{\star}=\mathrm{a}_{\max } / \mathrm{j}_{\max }Tj⋆​=amax​/jmax​, the acceleration reaches its maximum value and a segment with zero jerk may exist.

Then, the trajectory is feasible if

If this inequality holds, it is possible to compute the trajectory parameters. In this case, by defining the maximum value of the velocity during the motion as vlim =max⁡(q˙(t))\mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}=\max (\dot{q}(t))vlim ​=max(q˙​(t)), there are two possibilities:

Case 1: vlim =vmax \quad \mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}=\mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}vlim ​=vmax ​.

Case 2: vlim <vmax \mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}<\mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}vlim ​<vmax ​.

In the latter case, that can be verified only after the computation of the trajectory's parameters, the maximum velocity is not reached, and there is only an acceleration and a deceleration phase (no segment with constant velocity).

In both Case 1 and Case 2, it is possible that the maximum acceleration (positive or negative) is not reached. This may happen if the displacement is small, if the maximum allowed acceleration amax⁡\mathrm{a}_{\max }amax​ is high ("high dynamic" case), or if the initial (final) velocity is close enough to the maximum allowed speed. In these cases, the constant acceleration segment is not present. In particular, it is worth to notice that, because the different values of the initial and final velocities v0,v1v_{0}, v_{1}v0​,v1​, the amounts of time necessary to accelerate (from v0\mathrm{v}_{0}v0​ to vlim \mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}vlim ​ ) and to decelerate (from vlim \mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}vlim ​ to v1\mathrm{v}_{1}v1​ ) are in general different, and it may happen that the maximum acceleration amax⁡\mathrm{a}_{\max }amax​ is reached only in one of these phases, while in the other one the maximum acceleration is alim <amax \mathrm{a}_{\text {lim }}<\mathrm{a}_{\text {max }}alim ​<amax ​. Let us define:

Tj1T_{j 1}Tj1​ : time-interval in which the jerk is constant (jmax⁡\left(\mathrm{j}_{\max }\right.(jmax​ or jmin \mathrm{j}_{\text {min }}jmin ​ ) during the acceleration phase;

Tj2T_{j 2}Tj2​ : time-interval in which the jerk is constant (jmax \left(\mathrm{j}_{\text {max }}\right.(jmax ​ or jmin \mathrm{j}_{\text {min }}jmin ​ ) during the deceleration phase;

TaT_{a}Ta​ : acceleration period;

TvT_{v}Tv​ : constant velocity period;

TdT_{d}Td​ : deceleration period;

TTT : total duration of the trajectory (=Ta+Tv+Td)\left(=T_{a}+T_{v}+T_{d}\right)(=Ta​+Tv​+Td​)

Case 1: vlim =vmax \mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}=\mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}vlim ​=vmax ​.

In this case, it is possible to verify if the maximum acceleration ( amax⁡\mathrm{a}_{\max }amax​ or amin⁡=−amax⁡)\left.\mathrm{a}_{\min }=-\mathrm{a}_{\max }\right)amin​=−amax​) is reached by means of the following conditions:

 if (vmax⁡−v0)jmax⁡<amax⁡2⟹amax⁡ is not reached;  if (vmax⁡−v1)jmax⁡<amax⁡2⟹amin⁡ is not reached. \begin{align*} & \text { if }\left(\mathrm{v}_{\max }-\mathrm{v}_{0}\right) \mathrm{j}_{\max }<\mathrm{a}_{\max }^{2} \Longrightarrow \mathrm{a}_{\max } \quad \text { is not reached; } \tag{3.19}\\ & \text { if }\left(\mathrm{v}_{\max }-\mathrm{v}_{1}\right) \mathrm{j}_{\max }<\mathrm{a}_{\max }^{2} \Longrightarrow \mathrm{a}_{\min } \text { is not reached. } \tag{3.20} \end{align*}​ if (vmax​−v0​)jmax​<amax2​⟹amax​ is not reached;  if (vmax​−v1​)jmax​<amax2​⟹amin​ is not reached. ​(3.19)(3.20)​

Then, the time intervals of the acceleration segment can be computed if (3.19) holds as

Tj1=vmax⁡−v0jmax⁡,Ta=2Tj1\begin{equation*} T_{j 1}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{v}_{\max }-\mathrm{v}_{0}}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }}}, \quad T_{a}=2 T_{j 1} \tag{3.21} \end{equation*}Tj1​=jmax​vmax​−v0​​​,Ta​=2Tj1​​(3.21)​

otherwise as

Tj1=amax⁡jmax⁡,Ta=Tj1+vmax⁡−v0amax⁡\begin{equation*} T_{j 1}=\frac{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }}, \quad T_{a}=T_{j 1}+\frac{\mathrm{v}_{\max }-\mathrm{v}_{0}}{\mathrm{a}_{\max }} \tag{3.22} \end{equation*}Tj1​=jmax​amax​​,Ta​=Tj1​+amax​vmax​−v0​​​(3.22)​

The time intervals of the deceleration segment can be computed if (3.20) holds as

Tj2=vmax⁡−v1jmax⁡,Td=2Tj2\begin{equation*} T_{j 2}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{v}_{\max }-\mathrm{v}_{1}}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }}}, \quad T_{d}=2 T_{j 2} \tag{3.23} \end{equation*}Tj2​=jmax​vmax​−v1​​​,Td​=2Tj2​​(3.23)​

otherwise as

Tj2=amax⁡jmax⁡,Td=Tj2+vmax⁡−v1amax⁡\begin{equation*} T_{j 2}=\frac{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }}, \quad T_{d}=T_{j 2}+\frac{\mathrm{v}_{\max }-\mathrm{v}_{1}}{\mathrm{a}_{\max }} \tag{3.24} \end{equation*}Tj2​=jmax​amax​​,Td​=Tj2​+amax​vmax​−v1​​​(3.24)​

Finally, it is possible to determine the time duration of the constant velocity segment as

Tv=q1−q0vmax⁡−Ta2(1+v0vmax⁡)−Td2(1+v1vmax⁡)\begin{equation*} T_{v}=\frac{q_{1}-q_{0}}{\mathrm{v}_{\max }}-\frac{T_{a}}{2}\left(1+\frac{\mathrm{v}_{0}}{\mathrm{v}_{\max }}\right)-\frac{T_{d}}{2}\left(1+\frac{\mathrm{v}_{1}}{\mathrm{v}_{\max }}\right) \tag{3.25} \end{equation*}Tv​=vmax​q1​−q0​​−2Ta​​(1+vmax​v0​​)−2Td​​(1+vmax​v1​​)​(3.25)​

If Tv>0T_{v}>0Tv​>0, then the maximum velocity is actually reached and the values obtained by (3.21)-(3.25) can be used to compute the trajectory.

The condition Tv<0T_{v}<0Tv​<0 simply means that the maximum velocity vlim \mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}vlim ​ is smaller than vmax⁡\mathrm{v}_{\max }vmax​ and, therefore, the following Case 2 must be considered.

If Ta<2TjT_{a}<2 T_{j}Ta​<2Tj​ or Td<2TjT_{d}<2 T_{j}Td​<2Tj​, then the maximum (minimum) acceleration is not reached in at least one of the two segments, and therefore it is not possible to use eq. A possible way to determine this solution is to progressively decrease the value of amax⁡\mathrm{a}_{\max }amax​ (e.g. by assuming amax⁡=γamax⁡\mathrm{a}_{\max }=\gamma \mathrm{a}_{\max }amax​=γamax​, with 0<γ<10<\gamma<10<γ<1 ) and compute the durations of the segments by means of (3.26a), (3.26b), (3.26c), until the conditions Ta>2TjT_{a}>2 T_{j}Ta​>2Tj​ and Td>2TjT_{d}>2 T_{j}Td​>2Tj​ are both true.

3.4.1 Computation of the trajectory for q1>q0q_{1}>q_{0}q1​>q0​

Once the time lengths and the other parameters have been defined, the double S trajectory is computed by means of the following equations (one for each segment defined in Fig. 3.13). The case t0=0t_{0}=0t0​=0 is assumed, otherwise a translation in time has to be applied, see Sec. 5.1.

Acceleration phase

a) t∈[0,Tj1]t \in\left[0, T_{j 1}\right]t∈[0,Tj1​]

{q(t)=q0+v0t+jmax⁡t36q˙(t)=v0+jmax⁡t22q¨(t)=jmax⁡tq(3)(t)=jmax⁡(3.30a)\left\{\begin{array}{l} q(t)=q_{0}+\mathrm{v}_{0} t+\mathrm{j}_{\max } \frac{t^{3}}{6} \tag{3.30a}\\ \dot{q}(t)=\mathrm{v}_{0}+\mathrm{j}_{\max } \frac{t^{2}}{2} \\ \ddot{q}(t)=\mathrm{j}_{\max } t \\ q^{(3)}(t)=\mathrm{j}_{\max } \end{array}\right.⎩⎨⎧​q(t)=q0​+v0​t+jmax​6t3​q˙​(t)=v0​+jmax​2t2​q¨​(t)=jmax​tq(3)(t)=jmax​​(3.30a)

b) t∈[Tj1,Ta−Tj1]t \in\left[T_{j 1}, T_{a}-T_{j 1}\right]t∈[Tj1​,Ta​−Tj1​]

{q(t)=q0+v0t+alima6(3t2−3Tj1t+Tj12)q˙(t)=v0+alima(t−Tj12)q¨(t)=jmax⁡Tj1=alimaq(3)(t)=0(3.30b)\left\{\begin{array}{l} q(t)=q_{0}+\mathrm{v}_{0} t+\frac{\mathrm{a}_{l i m_{a}}}{6}\left(3 t^{2}-3 T_{j 1} t+T_{j 1}^{2}\right) \tag{3.30b}\\ \dot{q}(t)=\mathrm{v}_{0}+\mathrm{a}_{l i m_{a}}\left(t-\frac{T_{j 1}}{2}\right) \\ \ddot{q}(t)=\mathrm{j}_{\max } T_{j 1}=\mathrm{a}_{l i m_{a}} \\ q^{(3)}(t)=0 \end{array}\right.⎩⎨⎧​q(t)=q0​+v0​t+6alima​​​(3t2−3Tj1​t+Tj12​)q˙​(t)=v0​+alima​​(t−2Tj1​​)q¨​(t)=jmax​Tj1​=alima​​q(3)(t)=0​(3.30b)

3.4.2 Computation of the trajectory for q1 < q0

In case q1<q0q_{1}<q_{0}q1​<q0​, the parameters of the trajectory can be computed according to the same procedure reported above. It is necessary to consider the initial and final positions/velocities with opposite signs, and, after the computation, to invert the resulting profiles of position, velocity, acceleration, and jerk.

More generally, given any initial and final values for position and velocity (q^0,q^1,v^0,v^1)\left(\hat{q}_{0}, \hat{q}_{1}, \hat{\mathrm{v}}_{0}, \hat{\mathrm{v}}_{1}\right)(q^​0​,q^​1​,v^0​,v^1​), in order to compute the trajectory it is necessary to transform these values as

q0=σq^0,q1=σq^1,v0=σv^0,v1=σv^1\begin{equation*} q_{0}=\sigma \hat{q}_{0}, \quad q_{1}=\sigma \hat{q}_{1}, \quad \mathrm{v}_{0}=\sigma \hat{\mathrm{v}}_{0}, \quad \mathrm{v}_{1}=\sigma \hat{\mathrm{v}}_{1} \tag{3.31} \end{equation*}q0​=σq^​0​,q1​=σq^​1​,v0​=σv^0​,v1​=σv^1​​(3.31)​

where σ=sign⁡(q^0−q^1)\sigma=\operatorname{sign}\left(\hat{q}_{0}-\hat{q}_{1}\right)σ=sign(q^​0​−q^​1​). Similarly, also the constraints on maximum and minimum velocity, acceleration and jerk (v^max ,v^min ,a^max ,a^min ,j^max ,j^min )\left(\hat{\mathrm{v}}_{\text {max }}, \hat{\mathrm{v}}_{\text {min }}, \hat{\mathrm{a}}_{\text {max }}, \hat{\mathrm{a}}_{\text {min }}, \hat{\mathrm{j}}_{\text {max }}, \hat{\mathrm{j}}_{\text {min }}\right)(v^max ​,v^min ​,a^max ​,a^min ​,j^​max ​,j^​min ​) must be transformed:

{vmax⁡=(σ+1)2v^max +(σ−1)2v^min vmin⁡=(σ+1)2v^min +(σ−1)2v^max amax⁡=(σ+1)2a^max +(σ−1)2a^min amin⁡=(σ+1)2a^min +(σ−1)2a^max jmax⁡=(σ+1)2j^max +(σ−1)2j^min jmin⁡=(σ+1)2j^min +(σ−1)2j^max (3.32)\left\{\begin{array}{l} \mathrm{v}_{\max }=\frac{(\sigma+1)}{2} \hat{\mathrm{v}}_{\text {max }}+\frac{(\sigma-1)}{2} \hat{\mathrm{v}}_{\text {min }} \tag{3.32}\\ \mathrm{v}_{\min }=\frac{(\sigma+1)}{2} \hat{\mathrm{v}}_{\text {min }}+\frac{(\sigma-1)}{2} \hat{\mathrm{v}}_{\text {max }} \\ \mathrm{a}_{\max }=\frac{(\sigma+1)}{2} \hat{\mathrm{a}}_{\text {max }}+\frac{(\sigma-1)}{2} \hat{\mathrm{a}}_{\text {min }} \\ \mathrm{a}_{\min }=\frac{(\sigma+1)}{2} \hat{\mathrm{a}}_{\text {min }}+\frac{(\sigma-1)}{2} \hat{\mathrm{a}}_{\text {max }} \\ \mathrm{j}_{\max }=\frac{(\sigma+1)}{2} \hat{\mathrm{j}}_{\text {max }}+\frac{(\sigma-1)}{2} \hat{\mathrm{j}}_{\text {min }} \\ \mathrm{j}_{\min }=\frac{(\sigma+1)}{2} \hat{\mathrm{j}}_{\text {min }}+\frac{(\sigma-1)}{2} \hat{\mathrm{j}}_{\text {max }} \end{array}\right.⎩⎨⎧​vmax​=2(σ+1)​v^max ​+2(σ−1)​v^min ​vmin​=2(σ+1)​v^min ​+2(σ−1)​v^max ​amax​=2(σ+1)​a^max ​+2(σ−1)​a^min ​amin​=2(σ+1)​a^min ​+2(σ−1)​a^max ​jmax​=2(σ+1)​j^​max ​+2(σ−1)​j^​min ​jmin​=2(σ+1)​j^​min ​+2(σ−1)​j^​max ​​(3.32)

Finally, the computed profiles (i.e. q(t),q˙(t),q¨(t),q(3)(t))\left.q(t), \dot{q}(t), \ddot{q}(t), q^{(3)}(t)\right)q(t),q˙​(t),q¨​(t),q(3)(t)) must be transformed again as

{q^(t)=σq(t)q˙˙(t)=σq˙(t)q^¨(t)=σq¨(t)q^(3)(t)=σq(3)(t)(3.33)\left\{\begin{array}{l} \hat{q}(t)=\sigma q(t) \tag{3.33}\\ \dot{\dot{q}}(t)=\sigma \dot{q}(t) \\ \ddot{\hat{q}}(t)=\sigma \ddot{q}(t) \\ \hat{q}^{(3)}(t)=\sigma q^{(3)}(t) \end{array}\right.⎩⎨⎧​q^​(t)=σq(t)q˙​˙​(t)=σq˙​(t)q^​¨​(t)=σq¨​(t)q^​(3)(t)=σq(3)(t)​(3.33)

Flux diagram for the double S computation

3.4.3 Double S with null initial and final velocities

When the initial and final velocities v0\mathrm{v}_{0}v0​ and v1\mathrm{v}_{1}v1​ are null, the computation of the double S trajectory is much simpler, in particular when the constraints are symmetric (jmin⁡=−jmax ,amin =−amax ,vmin =−vmax )\left(\mathrm{j}_{\min }=-\mathrm{j}_{\text {max }}, \mathrm{a}_{\text {min }}=-\mathrm{a}_{\text {max }}, \mathrm{v}_{\text {min }}=-\mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}\right)(jmin​=−jmax ​,amin ​=−amax ​,vmin ​=−vmax ​).

Fig. 3.18. Flux diagram for the double S trajectory computation.

As a matter of fact, in this case the acceleration and deceleration segments are symmetric, and then Ta=TdT_{a}=T_{d}Ta​=Td​ and Tj1=Tj2=TjT_{j 1}=T_{j 2}=T_{j}Tj1​=Tj2​=Tj​. Moreover, it is always possible to find a trajectory joining the initial and the final position, which meets the constraints on velocity, acceleration and jerk.

Let us assume q1>q0q_{1}>q_{0}q1​>q0​ (otherwise consider Sec. 3.4.2). Four situations are possible:

  1. vlim =vmax \mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}=\mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}vlim ​=vmax ​ :

1.a. alim =amax⁡\mathrm{a}_{\text {lim }}=\mathrm{a}_{\max }alim ​=amax​

1.b. alim <amax⁡\mathrm{a}_{\text {lim }}<\mathrm{a}_{\max }alim ​<amax​

  1. vlim <vmax \mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}<\mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}vlim ​<vmax ​ :

2.a. alim =amax⁡\mathrm{a}_{\text {lim }}=\mathrm{a}_{\max }alim ​=amax​

2.b. alim <amax⁡\mathrm{a}_{\text {lim }}<\mathrm{a}_{\max }alim ​<amax​

where vlim \mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}vlim ​ and alim \mathrm{a}_{\text {lim }}alim ​ are the maximum values of velocity and acceleration actually reached during the trajectory, i.e. vlim =max⁡t(q˙(t))\mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}=\max _{t}(\dot{q}(t))vlim ​=maxt​(q˙​(t)) and alim =\mathrm{a}_{\text {lim }}=alim ​= max⁡t(q¨(t))\max _{t}(\ddot{q}(t))maxt​(q¨​(t)).

Case 1. vlim =vmax \mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}=\mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}vlim ​=vmax ​.

In this case, it is necessary to check if the maximum acceleration amax⁡\mathrm{a}_{\max }amax​ is reached or not, and then compute TjT_{j}Tj​ and Ta(=Td)T_{a}\left(=T_{d}\right)Ta​(=Td​)

 a. if vmax⁡jmax⁡≥amax⁡2⇒Tj=amax⁡jmax⁡Ta=Tj+vmax⁡amax⁡\text { a. if } \begin{aligned} \mathrm{v}_{\max } \mathrm{j}_{\max } \geq \mathrm{a}_{\max }^{2} \Rightarrow \quad T_{j} & =\frac{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }} \\ T_{a} & =T_{j}+\frac{\mathrm{v}_{\max }}{\mathrm{a}_{\max }} \end{aligned} a. if vmax​jmax​≥amax2​⇒Tj​Ta​​=jmax​amax​​=Tj​+amax​vmax​​​

 b. if vmax⁡jmax⁡<amax⁡2⇒Tj=vmax⁡jmax⁡Ta=2Tj\begin{aligned} & \text { b. if } \mathrm{v}_{\max } \mathrm{j}_{\max }<\mathrm{a}_{\max }^{2} \quad \Rightarrow \quad T_{j}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{v}_{\max }}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }}} \\ & T_{a}=2 T_{j} \end{aligned}​ b. if vmax​jmax​<amax2​⇒Tj​=jmax​vmax​​​Ta​=2Tj​​

Then, the duration of the constant velocity segment can be computed as

Tv=q1−q0vmax⁡−TaT_{v}=\frac{q_{1}-q_{0}}{\mathrm{v}_{\max }}-T_{a}Tv​=vmax​q1​−q0​​−Ta​

If TvT_{v}Tv​ is positive, the maximum velocity is reached, otherwise it is necessary to consider Case 2 (and Tv=0T_{v}=0Tv​=0 ).

Case 2. vlim <vmax \mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}<\mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}vlim ​<vmax ​.

Again, two sub-cases are possible, depending wether the maximum acceleration amax⁡\mathrm{a}_{\max }amax​ is reached or not. Also in this case the solution can be found in a closed form, as
a. if (q1−q0)≥2amax⁡3jmax⁡2⇒Tj=amax⁡jmax⁡Ta=Tj2+(Tj2)2+q1−q0amax⁡.\begin{aligned}\left(q_{1}-q_{0}\right) \geq 2 \frac{\mathrm{a}_{\max }^{3}}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }^{2}} \Rightarrow T_{j} & =\frac{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }} \\ T_{a} & =\frac{T_{j}}{2}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{T_{j}}{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{q_{1}-q_{0}}{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}} .\end{aligned}(q1​−q0​)≥2jmax2​amax3​​⇒Tj​Ta​​=jmax​amax​​=2Tj​​+(2Tj​​)2+amax​q1​−q0​​​.​

alim=jmax⁡Tj=alima=−alimdvlim=(Ta−Tj)alim\begin{aligned} & \mathrm{a}_{l i m}=\mathrm{j}_{\max } T_{j}=\mathrm{a}_{l i m_{a}}=-\mathrm{a}_{l i m_{d}} \\ & \mathrm{v}_{l i m}=\left(T_{a}-T_{j}\right) \mathrm{a}_{l i m} \end{aligned}​alim​=jmax​Tj​=alima​​=−alimd​​vlim​=(Ta​−Tj​)alim​​

3.4.4 On-line computation of the double S trajectory

A simplified approach for the computation of the double S profile is based on a discrete time formulation of the trajectory. This method is suitable when it is necessary to define complex trajectories, composed by several double S segments, and is appropriate for CNC machines, where the trajectory profiles are computed in discrete time.

Let us define

Fig. 3.19. Double S trajectory profiles with zero initial and final velocities, without a constant velocity phase and with limit acceleration lower than the maximum value.

{q(t=kTs)=qkq˙(t=kTs)=q˙kq¨(t=kTs)=q¨kq(3)(t=kTs)=qk(3)\begin{cases}q\left(t=k T_{s}\right) & =q_{k} \\ \dot{q}\left(t=k T_{s}\right) & =\dot{q}_{k} \\ \ddot{q}\left(t=k T_{s}\right) & =\ddot{q}_{k} \\ q^{(3)}\left(t=k T_{s}\right) & =q_{k}^{(3)}\end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​q(t=kTs​)q˙​(t=kTs​)q¨​(t=kTs​)q(3)(t=kTs​)​=qk​=q˙​k​=q¨​k​=qk(3)​​

the values of position, velocity, acceleration and jerk at the kkk-th time instant, being TsT_{s}Ts​ the sampling period. The structure of the trajectory planner is shown in Fig. 3.20. Given the initial and final values of position, velocity and acceleration and the constraints 2(vmax⁡,vmin⁡,amax⁡,amin⁡,jmax ,jmin ){ }^{2}\left(\mathrm{v}_{\max }, \mathrm{v}_{\min }, \mathrm{a}_{\max }, \mathrm{a}_{\min }, \mathrm{j}_{\text {max }}, \mathrm{j}_{\text {min }}\right)2(vmax​,vmin​,amax​,amin​,jmax ​,jmin ​), the jerk profile is computed as detailed below and then it is integrated three[^0]

Fig. 3.20. Block diagram of the trajectory planner for online computation of the double S trajectory.

times to obtain acceleration, velocity and position, respectively. In particular, the trapezoidal integration 3{ }^{3}3 is adopted, and accordingly the relations between jerk, acceleration, velocity and position are

q¨k=q¨k−1+Ts2(qk−1(3)+qk(3))q˙k=q˙k−1+Ts2(q¨k−1+q¨k)qk=qk−1+Ts2(q˙k−1+q˙k)\begin{align*} \ddot{q}_{k} & =\ddot{q}_{k-1}+\frac{T_{s}}{2}\left(q_{k-1}^{(3)}+q_{k}^{(3)}\right) \\ \dot{q}_{k} & =\dot{q}_{k-1}+\frac{T_{s}}{2}\left(\ddot{q}_{k-1}+\ddot{q}_{k}\right) \tag{3.34}\\ q_{k} & =q_{k-1}+\frac{T_{s}}{2}\left(\dot{q}_{k-1}+\dot{q}_{k}\right) \end{align*}q¨​k​q˙​k​qk​​=q¨​k−1​+2Ts​​(qk−1(3)​+qk(3)​)=q˙​k−1​+2Ts​​(q¨​k−1​+q¨​k​)=qk−1​+2Ts​​(q˙​k−1​+q˙​k​)​(3.34)​

The basic idea of this trajectory planner is to perform, with acceleration and jerk compliant with the desired constraints, the acceleration phase and then the constant velocity segment until it is necessary to decelerate in order to reach the final position q1q_{1}q1​ with the desired values of velocity and acceleration v1\mathrm{v}_{1}v1​ and a1\mathrm{a}_{1}a1​. Therefore, the computation of the trajectory is composed by two phases, see Fig. 3.21:

  1. An acceleration profile is computed with the classical trapezoidal acceleration, possibly followed by a constant velocity phase (=vmax )\left(=\mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}\right)(=vmax ​).
  2. During the motion, at each time instant kTsk T_{s}kTs​ it is checked whether it is possible to decelerate from the current velocity q˙k\dot{q}_{k}q˙​k​ to the final one v1\mathrm{v}_{1}v1​, with the constraints on q¨k\ddot{q}_{k}q¨​k​ and qk(3)q_{k}^{(3)}qk(3)​, and with the goal to reach exactly q1q_{1}q1​.

Phase 1: Acceleration and constant velocity phase

In order to perform a double S trajectory from q0q_{0}q0​ to q1(>q0)q_{1}\left(>q_{0}\right)q1​(>q0​), the jerk is kept at its maximum value until q¨k<amax⁡\ddot{q}_{k}<\mathrm{a}_{\max }q¨​k​<amax​. Then, the jerk is set to zero (qk(3)=0)\left(q_{k}^{(3)}=0\right)(qk(3)​=0), and therefore the acceleration is constant (amax⁡\left(\mathrm{a}_{\max }\right.(amax​ ). Finally, the jerk is set to the minimum value (qk(3)=jmin⁡)\left(q_{k}^{(3)}=\mathrm{j}_{\min }\right)(qk(3)​=jmin​) in order to have a null acceleration when the maximum velocity is reached. At this point, the maximum velocity is maintained until the deceleration phase starts.

Mathematically, this can be described by

3.4.5 Displacement time of a double S trajectory

The computation of the displacement time of a double S trajectory is rather complex, because of the large number of different possible cases. For this reason, only some specific, but common, situations are considered here.

In particular, assuming h=q1−q0>0h=q_{1}-q_{0}>0h=q1​−q0​>0, symmetric constraints vmin =\mathrm{v}_{\text {min }}=vmin ​= −vmax ,amin =−amax ,jmin =−jmax -\mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}, \mathrm{a}_{\text {min }}=-\mathrm{a}_{\text {max }}, \mathrm{j}_{\text {min }}=-\mathrm{j}_{\text {max }}−vmax ​,amin ​=−amax ​,jmin ​=−jmax ​, and that the maximum values of both acceleration and speed ( amax⁡\mathrm{a}_{\max }amax​ and vmax⁡\mathrm{v}_{\max }vmax​ ) are reached, the total duration of the trajectory can be easily obtained as

T=hvmax⁡+Ta2(1−v0vmax )+Td2(1−v1vmax )\begin{equation*} T=\frac{h}{\mathrm{v}_{\max }}+\frac{T_{a}}{2}\left(1-\frac{\mathrm{v}_{0}}{\mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}}\right)+\frac{T_{d}}{2}\left(1-\frac{\mathrm{v}_{1}}{\mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}}\right) \tag{3.39} \end{equation*}T=vmax​h​+2Ta​​(1−vmax ​v0​​)+2Td​​(1−vmax ​v1​​)​(3.39)​

with

Ta=amax⁡jmax⁡+vmax⁡−v0amax⁡,Td=amax⁡jmax⁡+vmax⁡−v1amax⁡T_{a}=\frac{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }}+\frac{\mathrm{v}_{\max }-\mathrm{v}_{0}}{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}, \quad T_{d}=\frac{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }}+\frac{\mathrm{v}_{\max }-\mathrm{v}_{1}}{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}Ta​=jmax​amax​​+amax​vmax​−v0​​,Td​=jmax​amax​​+amax​vmax​−v1​​

If both initial and final speeds are zero, (3.39) becomes

T=hvmax⁡+vmax⁡amax⁡+amax⁡jmax⁡\begin{equation*} T=\frac{h}{\mathrm{v}_{\max }}+\frac{\mathrm{v}_{\max }}{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}+\frac{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }} \tag{3.40} \end{equation*}T=vmax​h​+amax​vmax​​+jmax​amax​​​(3.40)​

From eq. (3.40), it is straightforward to verify that the time length of the trajectory can be easily modified by properly scaling the values of vmax ,amax \mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}, \mathrm{a}_{\text {max }}vmax ​,amax ​, jmax \mathrm{j}_{\text {max }}jmax ​. As a matter of fact, if the new constraints

vmax⁡′=λvmax⁡,amax⁡′=λ2amax⁡,jmax⁡′=λ3jmax⁡\mathrm{v}_{\max }^{\prime}=\lambda \mathrm{v}_{\max }, \quad \mathrm{a}_{\max }^{\prime}=\lambda^{2} \mathrm{a}_{\max }, \quad \mathrm{j}_{\max }^{\prime}=\lambda^{3} \mathrm{j}_{\max }vmax′​=λvmax​,amax′​=λ2amax​,jmax′​=λ3jmax​

are considered, the duration T′T^{\prime}T′ becomes

T′=TλT^{\prime}=\frac{T}{\lambda}T′=λT​

and therefore it is possible to compute the value of λ\lambdaλ which leads to a desired duration T′=TDT^{\prime}=T_{D}T′=TD​ :

λ=TTD\lambda=\frac{T}{T_{D}}λ=TD​T​

The same considerations are valid also if the initial and final velocities are not null, but in this case it is necessary to scale also v0\mathrm{v}_{0}v0​ and v1\mathrm{v}_{1}v1​ (see eq. (3.39)):

v0′=λv0,v1′=λv1\mathrm{v}_{0}^{\prime}=\lambda \mathrm{v}_{0}, \quad \mathrm{v}_{1}^{\prime}=\lambda \mathrm{v}_{1}v0′​=λv0​,v1′​=λv1​

For other considerations about the scaling in time of trajectories, see Chapter 5 .

Example 3.17 In Fig. 3.26 the position, velocity, acceleration and jerk of a double S trajectory with a total duration TD=5 sT_{D}=5 \mathrm{~s}TD​=5 s are shown. The boundary conditions and the constraints are the same of Example 3.9, which lead to the time length T=2.71 sT=2.71 \mathrm{~s}T=2.71 s. In order to modify the duration of the trajectory and to obtain the desired value TDT_{D}TD​, the constraints and the initial and final velocities are scaled by λ=0.542\lambda=0.542λ=0.542.

3.4.6 Double S trajectory with assigned duration of the different phases

A general approach for planning a double SSS trajectory, with a given time length TTT and with specified durations of the acceleration and of the constant jerk phases, consists in defining the values of vmax⁡,amax⁡\mathrm{v}_{\max }, \mathrm{a}_{\max }vmax​,amax​, and jmax \mathrm{j}_{\text {max }}jmax ​ as a function

Fig. 3.26. Double S trajectory profiles (position, velocity, acceleration and jerk) properly scaled to impose a desired duration (TD=5 s)\left(T_{D}=5 \mathrm{~s}\right)(TD​=5 s).

of the desired T,Ta,Td,TjT, T_{a}, T_{d}, T_{j}T,Ta​,Td​,Tj​. In particular, the symmetric case with vmin⁡=\mathrm{v}_{\min }=vmin​= −vmax ,amin =−amax⁡,jmin =−jmax -\mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}, \mathrm{a}_{\text {min }}=-\mathrm{a}_{\max }, \mathrm{j}_{\text {min }}=-\mathrm{j}_{\text {max }}−vmax ​,amin ​=−amax​,jmin ​=−jmax ​ is considered, and the initial and final velocities v0,v1\mathrm{v}_{0}, \mathrm{v}_{1}v0​,v1​ are both assumed to be zero (therefore Td=TaT_{d}=T_{a}Td​=Ta​ ). Moreover, it is supposed that both the maximum speed and the maximum acceleration are reached. Therefore, with reference to equations (3.30a)-(3.30g) which define the trajectory profiles, it results

vlim =vmax⁡,alim⁡a=alim⁡d=amax⁡\mathrm{v}_{\text {lim }}=\mathrm{v}_{\max }, \quad \mathrm{a}_{\lim _{a}}=\mathrm{a}_{\lim _{d}}=\mathrm{a}_{\max }vlim ​=vmax​,alima​​=alimd​​=amax​

From the expressions of the total duration, of the time length of acceleration phase and of the constant jerk segment, i.e.

Fig. 3.27. Double S trajectory profiles with zero initial and final velocities, and with desired durations of the single tracts.

{T=hvmax⁡+TaTa=vmax⁡amax⁡+TjTj=amax⁡jmax⁡\left\{\begin{align*} T & =\frac{h}{\mathrm{v}_{\max }}+T_{a} \tag{3.41}\\ T_{a} & =\frac{\mathrm{v}_{\max }}{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}+T_{j} \\ T_{j} & =\frac{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }} \end{align*}\right.⎩⎨⎧​TTa​Tj​​=vmax​h​+Ta​=amax​vmax​​+Tj​=jmax​amax​​​(3.41)​

it is possible to deduce the corresponding values of vmax ,amax ,jmax \mathrm{v}_{\text {max }}, \mathrm{a}_{\text {max }}, \mathrm{j}_{\text {max }}vmax ​,amax ​,jmax ​ :

{vmax⁡=hT−Taamax⁡=h(T−Ta)(Ta−Tj)jmax⁡=h(T−Ta)(Ta−Tj)Tj\left\{\begin{aligned} \mathrm{v}_{\max } & =\frac{h}{T-T_{a}} \\ \mathrm{a}_{\max } & =\frac{h}{\left(T-T_{a}\right)\left(T_{a}-T_{j}\right)} \\ \mathrm{j}_{\max } & =\frac{h}{\left(T-T_{a}\right)\left(T_{a}-T_{j}\right) T_{j}} \end{aligned}\right.⎩⎨⎧​vmax​amax​jmax​​=T−Ta​h​=(T−Ta​)(Ta​−Tj​)h​=(T−Ta​)(Ta​−Tj​)Tj​h​​

If one assumes that the acceleration period is a fraction of the entire trajectory duration:

Ta=αT,0<α≤1/2T_{a}=\alpha T, \quad 0<\alpha \leq 1 / 2Ta​=αT,0<α≤1/2

and, in a similar manner, that the time length of the constant jerk phase is a fraction of the acceleration period:

Tj=βTa,0<β≤1/2T_{j}=\beta T_{a}, \quad 0<\beta \leq 1 / 2Tj​=βTa​,0<β≤1/2

then the values of the maximum speed, acceleration and jerk of the double S trajectory q(t)q(t)q(t) are obtained as:

{vmax⁡=h(1−α)Tamax⁡=hα(1−α)(1−β)T2jmax⁡=hα2β(1−α)(1−β)T3\left\{\begin{align*} \mathrm{v}_{\max } & =\frac{h}{(1-\alpha) T} \tag{3.42}\\ \mathrm{a}_{\max } & =\frac{h}{\alpha(1-\alpha)(1-\beta) T^{2}} \\ \mathrm{j}_{\max } & =\frac{h}{\alpha^{2} \beta(1-\alpha)(1-\beta) T^{3}} \end{align*}\right.⎩⎨⎧​vmax​amax​jmax​​=(1−α)Th​=α(1−α)(1−β)T2h​=α2β(1−α)(1−β)T3h​​(3.42)​

By substituting these values in (3.30a)-(3.30g), the trajectory with the given durations is defined.

Obviously, the equations (3.41) which relate the variables of the double S trajectory ( vmax⁡,amax ,jmax ,h,T,Ta,Tj\mathrm{v}_{\max }, \mathrm{a}_{\text {max }}, \mathrm{j}_{\text {max }}, h, T, T_{a}, T_{j}vmax​,amax ​,jmax ​,h,T,Ta​,Tj​ ) can also be solved with respect to other sets of variables, e.g. ( vmax⁡,amax⁡,Tj)\left.\mathrm{v}_{\max }, \mathrm{a}_{\max }, T_{j}\right)vmax​,amax​,Tj​), or (vmax⁡,Ta,Tj)\left(\mathrm{v}_{\max }, T_{a}, T_{j}\right)(vmax​,Ta​,Tj​), and so on, if the other terms are known. For instance, if one desires a trajectory with a total duration TTT and with a given maximum acceleration and jerk values amax⁡,jmax⁡\mathrm{a}_{\max }, \mathrm{j}_{\max }amax​,jmax​, it is possible to obtain the remaining coefficients as

{vmax⁡=−amax⁡2+amax⁡jmax⁡T−amax⁡(−4hjmax⁡2+amax⁡(amax⁡−jmax⁡T)2)2jmax⁡Ta=amax⁡2+amax⁡jmax⁡T−amax⁡(−4jmax⁡2+amax⁡(amax⁡−jmax⁡T)2)2amax⁡jmax⁡Tj=amax⁡jmax⁡\left\{\begin{aligned} \mathrm{v}_{\max } & =\frac{-\mathrm{a}_{\max }^{2}+\mathrm{a}_{\max } \mathrm{j}_{\max } T-\sqrt{\mathrm{a}_{\max }\left(-4 h \mathrm{j}_{\max }^{2}+\mathrm{a}_{\max }\left(\mathrm{a}_{\max }-\mathrm{j}_{\max } T\right)^{2}\right)}}{2 \mathrm{j}_{\max }} \\ T_{a} & =\frac{\mathrm{a}_{\max }^{2}+\mathrm{a}_{\max } \mathrm{j}_{\max } T-\sqrt{\mathrm{a}_{\max }\left(-4 \mathrm{j}_{\max }^{2}+\mathrm{a}_{\max }\left(\mathrm{a}_{\max }-\mathrm{j}_{\max } T\right)^{2}\right)}}{2 \mathrm{a}_{\max } \mathrm{j}_{\max }} \\ T_{j} & =\frac{\mathrm{a}_{\max }}{\mathrm{j}_{\max }} \end{aligned}\right.⎩⎨⎧​vmax​Ta​Tj​​=2jmax​−amax2​+amax​jmax​T−amax​(−4hjmax2​+amax​(amax​−jmax​T)2)​​=2amax​jmax​amax2​+amax​jmax​T−amax​(−4jmax2​+amax​(amax​−jmax​T)2)​​=jmax​amax​​​

Example 3.19 A double S trajectory with the boundary conditions

q0=0,q1=10,v0=0,v1=0q_{0}=0, \quad q_{1}=10, \quad \mathrm{v}_{0}=0, \quad \mathrm{v}_{1}=0q0​=0,q1​=10,v0​=0,v1​=0

is computed with the purpose of obtaining a total duration T=5T=5T=5. Moreover, the constraints

amax⁡=2,jmax⁡=8\mathrm{a}_{\max }=2, \quad \mathrm{j}_{\max }=8amax​=2,jmax​=8

are considered. The resulting values of the velocity, and of duration of the constant acceleration and jerk phases are

vmax⁡=3,Ta=1.82,Tj=0.25\mathrm{v}_{\max }=3, \quad T_{a}=1.82, \quad T_{j}=0.25vmax​=3,Ta​=1.82,Tj​=0.25

They define the trajectory reported in Fig. 3.29.
